abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project was satisfactory.
            Substantial objectives were met, with considerable
            under-runs, namely due to a highly competitive environment,
            in particular, the offshore pipeline. Although the lessons
            learned from this project, are no different than many other
            projects, in that government commitment and ownership is
            paramount for success, risk mitigation should be pursued,
            and, efficient and consistent teams are advantageous during
            project cycle, some major lessons are brought under
            consideration: 1) Despite the existing rule for
            pre-qualification of bidders, it is important to reiterate
            the Bank's Procurement Guidelines, even when financing
            is provided through non-Bank funds. This would ensure
            governments of the soundness of the various prospective
            contractors. 2) The outcome of projects is particularly
            based on the quality and firmness of supervision, which
            pursues compliance with covenants. It was this persistence
            which successfully brought to conclusion a delayed
            Corporatization/Privatization study, a basic document in the
            far reaching organizational and strategic reform of the
            Petroleum Authority of Thailand. 3) The pace of reforms
            should largely be left to the borrower's judgement, for
            it is the incremental, sequential, and steady approaches
            which provide a sustainable likelihood. Much of the project
            success was due to mutual trust between the Bank and the Borrower.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Gas
            Transmission Project are to promote greater sector
            efficiency and increase the utilization of domestic natural
            gas resources.  As such, the project will help the Petroleum
            Authority of Thailand (PTT) to: 1) move toward a fully
            commercial operation under the new organization, as well as
            continue previous efforts to strengthen its institutional
            capacity to apply safety and environmental standards and
            conduct project analyses including investment programming
            and 2) construct a pipeline for transporting domestic gas.
            The project components include: 1) a comprehensive study
            regarding PTT corporate strategy, organizational
            effectiveness, and ownership structure; 2) institutional
            building and training of PTT staff; 3) a 36-inch diameter,
            425 km offshore gas transmission pipeline that extends from
            an existing platform at the Erawan fields in the  Gulf of
            Thailand to onshore receiving facilities at Rayong; 4) a
            28-inch diameter, 110 km onshore pipeline that extends from
            Rayong to an area near the EGAT power plant at Bang Pakong;
            5) related facilities, including a compressor station,
            metering stations, gas processing facilities, and
            telecommunications and control systems; and 6) project
            engineering and management consultancy services.

repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Second Gas Transmission Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental impact
            assessment of the Second Gas Transmission Project for
            Thailand.  The project consists of supply and construction
            of a gas transmission system including related ancillary
            facilities.  The potential soil erosion and terrestrial
            ecology impact can be mitigated by a minimization of the
            clearing area and backfilling and replacement of groundcover
            after pipeline burial.  The marine water quality and the
            aquatic biology may be affected by sea bottom disturbance,
            waste disposal, chemical discharge from the hydrostatic
            test, and gas leakage from the pipeline.  These can be
            mitigated by the selection of spoil areas for trenching,
            placing gravel at spans, prohibition of waste dumping,
            provision of onboard waste receptacles, the use of proper
            hydrostatic test chemicals, and the installation of on-line
            gas leakage and pressure change detection systems.  The
            public health/safety impacts during construction come from
            possible health problems and accidents, living conditions in
            the construction camps, and possible gas leakage.  These are
            mitigated by the provision of proper health and
            environmental sanitation, adequate safety devices, and
            stringent regulations combined with comprehensive training
            programs.  The anticipated impacts are mostly short term and
            relatively minor.  Furthermore, the mitigation measures
            proposed will reduce the impacts to acceptable levels.
